author: sinaigimenez
content:
Today I got a reminder of how important love and care are in what we do. Just wanna give a shoutout to @Nomograph Mastering for all the wisdom shared here on that topic.

Long story short — I agreed to mix a track for an American rapper who had already been turned down by some A-list mixers, even though the guy had a decent budget. The reason was kinda obvious: he’s got a personality that leans toward OCD, with everything that comes with that — defensive tone in convos, super long mix notes, and weird stuff like thinking a file sounds different just because it was renamed. (I forgot to label one file as “ref. limited” like the previous versions, and even though it was literally the exact same file, he swore the “non-limited” one had a different top end.)

Stuff like that made me seriously consider walking away from the project like the others did — I could just feel the back-and-forth drama coming. But after my first instinct, I remembered a lot of what’s been talked about here: love, care, and being open to the music and the art. So I decided to try empathy instead of just being a jerk out of frustration.

And honestly? It worked. After taking a bit of time to really talk to him and show I genuinely wanted to help — not just as a mixer, but as a human — I learned he’s totally burnt out and running on fumes 'cause he just became a dad. And I totally get that, since my first kid was born a month ago too. That connection shifted the whole vibe. The next round of notes actually made sense, and we ended up approving the first mix by version 4 — which isn’t bad at all. Happy client, job done.

Not saying you should hang onto toxic clients, but it was a solid reminder: don’t always go with your first reaction. Sometimes just showing a little care  about the person on the other side can change everything. It did for me this time. And tbh, I don’t think I would’ve handled it this way if I hadn’t read some of the stuff shared here. So thanks, y’all. This place is gold.

author: NoahNeedleman
content: “Nobody tells this to people who are beginners, I wish someone told me. All of us who do creative work, we get into it because we have good taste. But there is this gap. For the first couple years you make stuff, it’s just not that good. It’s trying to be good, it has potential, but it’s not. But your taste, the thing that got you into the game, is still killer. And your taste is why your work disappoints you. A lot of people never get past this phase, they quit. Most people I know who do interesting, creative work went through years of this. We know our work doesn’t have this special thing that we want it to have. We all go through this. And if you are just starting out or you are still in this phase, you gotta know its normal and the most important thing you can do is do a lot of work. Put yourself on a deadline so that every week you will finish one story. It is only by going through a volume of work that you will close that gap, and your work will be as good as your ambitions. And I took longer to figure out how to do this than anyone I’ve ever met. It’s gonna take awhile. It’s normal to take awhile. You’ve just gotta fight your way through.” - Ira Glass

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Yes. Do all of it. Show your work, show your process, reach out to people, etc etc 

Spend some time doing ALL of it, and then figure out what rhythms and processes you feel authentic doing. Everything new always feels weird. But suffer though that and find some ways it works for you.

And think through it. You *could* send a bunch of DMs that say "hey you don't know me but listen to my work because I want to work with you." Probably send 100 and get a small percentage of those messages returns. Or maybe you should start by posting things you love and tagging the artists. Then if they respond say "man I'm such a big fan of XYZ song, the way you blah blah blah" and start things that way. No right or wrong ways. But just use the medium and see what you come up with.

It's SOCIAL media. If you treat it like "how can I promote myself," that might work. But if you treat it like a platform for interacting and sharing with people and artists and music you love, you'll probably have more success that way.

Also, it can be a dopamine time suck that eats away at your interactions with the physical world.

So you just gotta be intentional and see what your capacities are.

author: BatMeckley
content:
No. 
No no. 
No to the hell nah no. 
This is why I keep telling people how important it is to develop their taste. 
Alex shares similar sonic traits with his Dad because he grew up listening to someone go, “Christ there’s so much wooliness in this vocal, we need to get it up to where the audience can hear the words” or “let’s cut some space HERE in the track so that THIS sits”. The whole secret is the WHY, not the fact that he gifted him a MH Channel strip license. 

I’ve been really into photography lately, and I’m constantly struck by how my professional photographer little brother constantly gets better results than i do on worse gear. And it’s because he knows what to look for in a photograph, and then it’s easy enough to work backwards from there. That’s the skill of the whole thing. And it’s such a strong parallel to watching the Machine Head collectors on gearspace or the $12k PRS blues lawyers on TGP wax poetic about gear while clearly having no idea what the gear is actually used for. 

Focus on the right things.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
On the food analogy:

Making food that is nutritious is not hard. A pile of kale, a bowl of plain beans, an avocado, maybe a fish, and a glass of water and you've got nutrition.

Making the first bite taste amazing isn't hard either. Add a ton of salt sugar and oil, maybe fry it. That'll hit 98% of people's taste buds hard immediately.

The challenge is not doing either, but doing both. 

Same is true for music.

First listen great, 1000th listen great, and have that effect on the most number of people. That's my favorite kind of music.

author: Rob Domos
content:
Love the whole conversation above. 

One thing to consider with the whole “people hire me for my taste” thing is that it’s important to have not only a refined palate, but also a broad enough one to be collaborating. 

I’ve worked with extremely talented people who don’t have the breadth to apply their skills to something even slightly outside of their *exact* preference, and I perceive that as being to their detriment. 

If you want to be a professional chef and you make incredible arrabbiata but begrudgingly phone it in with alfredo, you’re going to have a pretty poor career telling Italian restaurants that you’re the right guy for arrabbiata and the wrong guy for alfredo. That’s niching down a little too hard a little too early.

I think it’s our job to find the essence within something and maximally bring that essence out. Often these “taste mismatch” issues come across to me as missing that essence within the thing you’re working on and trying to make it something that it essentially isn’t. ie. A wannabe Max Martin working with a wannabe mitski and the producer complaining that the artist’s suggestions are making the production hashy and the artist complaining that the producer’s production choices don’t convey enough emotion. 

It’s talking past each-other and not really collaborating. You aren’t learning to truly love what your partner loves, which IMO is frankly a big part of the job.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
What’s interesting about these 3 particular sliders is that the way they interact… is the *opposite* of zero sum. 

Studying the classics teaches us to read well, write well, and, most importantly, *think* well. Being intentional and understanding which rules need breaking and why… without that grounding we often end up recapitulating old ideas *thinking* we’re doing something new. 

I truly am a specialist in music, but my creativity and perspective are fueled by other things I do at a generalist level, like cooking & photography. 

I have long term goals that are only realized by doing what’s in front of me. Journey of a thousand miles and all.

author: Chad Rodgers
content:
For my day job (which I leave in 2 weeks for music fuuuuck 😱) I create presentations and eLearnings for some big companies. 

There’s a neat framework called Bloom’s Taxonomy which I use all the time to benchmark the value of the learning objectives. If what you’re “teaching” doesn’t link with one of these, you’re probably not teaching. And on the hierarchy you want to ideally be closer to the top. The lower you go, the less applicable the thing is and the less useful.

Many of these entertainment videos masking themselves as learning videos probably correspond with the lowermost rung on the taxonomy when I think about it. You’ll go away recalling basic concepts and ideas but not creating, evaluating, applying it etc…

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
There’s a few questions there so one at a time I guess. I’m just going to answer what you asked directly, and maybe this week I can take a shot at answering what I think are the underlying themes..

**How do you approach your craft now, in terms of attention to detail**

Nothing has changed in terms of my attention to detail, everything gets the same love as it always did. The stakes for errors have gone up - when they are manufacturing 100k copies of vinyl then you have to be sure it’s error free

**Do you reject artists if they approach you to “Master my album i’ll pay you whatever you want” if you think the level of their sound might not honour your history with all these artists**

I don’t reject *anyone* who can pay my rate. I don’t vet clients on a “how will you make me look?” basis, I’m a service provider to them. There are very very occasionally mismatches where I’ll say “happy to do this but I think you’d be better served by XYZ”, an example being someone coming to me with EDM who wants really intense processing - another girl or guy steeped in that genre will serve them better

**How does it feel having a connection to these artists?**

It feels really nice to be trusted with people’s art, when someone like a St. Vincent says “yeah, this is good” it matters to me, she has great ears and taste so it feels good to hit a mark

It’s also very special to hear these things come out of the speaker for the first time - I’ll never forget hearing Nick Cave, or Taylor or Lana in the room for the first time. It’s a privilege to be trusted with their art

**but does it ever happen that you are wanting more?”**

I’m human and can be reliably trusted to do all the silly human things like being greedy, insecure, fearful etc. but every year I get a little better at living a better way, and around the music in particular my operating principles “The why” feel better and truer than they ever have

author: Edward Rivera
content:
In meditative practice, there are exercises one does to mentally inhabit some bleak scenarios in order to invoke gratitude. 

Like, imagine you died yesterday…vividly…the last thing you’ll have said to your partner is the last thing you’ll have ever said, the last interaction with your dog is set in stone, as is the last thing you ate, or the last emotion you had…Yesterday was your last day on earth. 

Now imagine that you’ve been given a second chance at this life, you’ve been brought back to existence and can once again see your partner, your dog, eat food, and embody new emotions. How would that experience be / feel different ? 

And can you invoke that feeling today, right now ?

author: cian riordan
content: Eventually I caught the hang of things. I started to study the rhythms of the sessions, what order people would file in every morning. I knew the singer liked coffee one way, another guy did something else… I’d start to have that stuff ready. Instead of chumming it up with the band trying to fend off boredom while Eric was mid task, I stuck around on the couch… watching patiently. Those were the moments where he would start looping me into what he was doing, explaining his techniques. Before I knew it, I could start anticipating what he would need next. Someone mentions trying some vocals on a thing? I immediately got going on setting up a mic, getting headphones, even starting to dial in a mix on the headphone box. Percussion? Grab the trunk of junk and start laying out potential options. Once I started actually being useful, I’d be given real tasks. “Hey, do you think you could try doing a preliminary comp of this vocal?” I had been in the room for all the vocal takes, heard the discussion about approach and vibe, even made the singers coffee the right way… why not? That evolved into being trusted with recording stuff in the second studio… we were always running behind, and having me chip away at guitar tracking or re-amping was really useful. Years of this and we were a well oiled machine. I’d get looped into pre-production phone calls and meetings, he would start asking my opinion on things.. drum sounds, microphone choices.

author: thegreatcarsoni
content:
Awesome. I'm seeing this right now with a friend's band, so ima jump on the bandwagon here. I just took over mixing the album, which has been in progress for years. Everybody tells me the producer/band leader is this prolific asshole, constantly blowing up at people and impossible to please. The previous mixer had been mixing this thing for months/over a year and everyone was worn out/not getting results. I was really reluctant to take on the project for fear of being intimidated/failing to deliver.

I've made a point of greeting the producer at every step with clear communication, enthusiasm, and an open mind. I genuinely love the music and have made a point of letting him know how much fun it's been to work on the stuff. And, similar to your story, we were basically approved on the first track within 4 mixes and the guy seemed really really happy.

Everyone just said this guy was a hopeless asshole, but what I saw was a guy who was working so hard to bring a vision to life and just struggling to get there; self-financing, overseeing everything, etc... and it's fairly complex, hip hop and soul vibes with practically a full orchestra and 3 vocalists, so it's a lot to manage. Not trying to excuse the asshole behavior, but I see the frustration and I really wanted to highlight how much cool work he had done and that, without any fuss or needless back and forth, we would just get it where it needed to go. i tried to just think about how exciting it could be to finally hear these songs that've been bouncing around in his head actually come out of the speaker the way he imagined. We've got 7 songs almost done now and I've grown so much just from these attitude alignments i've picked up from spending time here.

author: Rollmottle
content: Many songs come out of the mixing stage sounding "done." Those songs could still benefit from perspective. I would not describe that as "a lot of the mastering processes happening in the mixing stage." For me, mastering is the process by which I 100% align the final product with the artistic intent. There's a technical component to that, but there's also a huge component of that that is pure vibe. Can I enhance the feeling of this song without getting in the way? Is the feeling of this song fully realized? Is the feeling of these songs together fully realized? Uncovering all that to me is the job. Sometimes it's already there and there's very little, if anything, to do. The perspective is still valuable. The key here is somebody who both understands the technical aspects of the job as well as somebody who can internalize and FEEL the music. The latter is why I believe mastering is one of the most misunderstood processes.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
It sucks when someone comes down on you for anything tho. Like I am absolutely the hardest on myself, so anyone else tryna be hard on me feels immediately like piling on. Tough to hold your cool through that. 

When I worked at the Cheesecake Factory in my early 20s, the regional manager was a woman larger than the man who was the local gm, and whenever she came to town he’d get real meddlesome and annoying to his staff, making us all worried that somehow our normal workflow wasn’t good enough. It was bad vibes. 

But I’ll never forget a coworker coming over to me and saying, “can you imagine the two of them having sex?” And then walking away like servers do after dropping a one-liner at a table. 

I laughed, but honestly it changed my entire perspective on managers or bosses or anyone in authority. They’re just people, dealing with their own anxieties either heroically or poorly, and I can choose how much of that take on myself. And if I do choose to, I do it out of compassion, not fear. 

… I hope that makes sense.

author: bobby k
content:
Been pondering..a few thoughts:
-prioritizing health & productivity are not mutually exclusive, in fact they are easily aligned. A shorter work day that began with a workout is almost always more fruitful than a longer day grinding away
-not everything needs to be said with words, not everything needs to be a conversation. body language, silence, or taking initiative on a task all do a lot on their own. 
-deep breaths and letting the emotions process and pass before responding almost always yields a better interaction, in business and in relationships
-nobody really needs to know how hard you worked.
-you’re not Superman, there will be things left unfinished each day (music/work, house projects/house chores). Having a system of prioritizing helps foster peace with the unfinished stuff

author: BatMeckley
content:
Over in the meme channel @Jeremy Klein said something about his grandpa saying “why don’t you play something that’s people actually like”. I’ve been thinking about it a lot lately, and whether or not people should work on developing their, let’s say “musical taste” as much as they develop their technical skill. 

It always breaks my heart to see music school grads know a million chords but not have any idea on how to put them together in a away that other people would enjoy. Also, who the hell is to say what qualifies as “taste”. But I’ve heard too many people argue without a sense of irony about the 5k on a song that is just at its heart completely unlistenable. 

Can taste be developed? Should it be?

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
So I’m with Beckley on this. I get hired because of my taste, and I go into projects with full communication re: what is intended. 

I don’t say “this sucks I’m gonna fix it.” I say “I have some ideas about how to pull this into a really kickass place.” 

Very rarely as a mixer am I *only* mixing. Bass comes in and has no booty? Chances are I’m gonna be doing more than bx-subsynth to make it thump. Only tracked one guitar and it’s supposed to be huge? I’m gonna add some to really make that sell. 

I don’t always assume I know more than the artist, but the truth is, with the level of artists I usually work with, MOST of the time I do. 

That’s not an ego trip, it’s an understanding of the gig. It’s why people hire me. Why they ask for my help. And I treat that with deep respect. 

Last night Rauirí basically bullied me into buying RX standard for a project I was doing as a favor to a friend. I SPENT MONEY to do this thing. Because as Rauirí says: “Art matters.” 

And as Beckley ranted yesterday, I don’t think we should let something suck because we were only hired for a job. We’re not house painters who decided to fix a furnace. We’re general contractors who know how a house is built, and we fix shit that’s broken. (Bad example, but you get it.)

author: Slow Hand
content:
Fun question! I hate to complicate an already nuanced premise at the outset, but when I observe my own choices and think of each category I see myself living both sides of all three spectrums, but in different domains:

**For example:** I could be short-term in career objectives and overt achievement and long-term oriented in relationships and satisfaction. Cutting edge in creative pursuits, but classics in my personal taste. Specialist in my mode of expression, and generalist in my interests.

The more I subdivide and examine the question the more I find exceptions to everything. I am steeped in knowledge, but I seek wisdom above most things, which some philosophies would consider contradictory.

This Anais Nin quote comes to mind:

> "We do not grow absolutely, chronologically. We grow sometimes in one dimension, and not in another, unevenly. We grow partially. We are relative. We are mature in one realm, childish in another. The past, present, and future mingle and pull us backward, forward, or fix us in the present. We are made of layers, cells, constellations."

I think people are extremely lopsided and unbalanced when you start to drill down into their psyches, and that's wonderful! 

For the sake of refining this question and narrowing the scope, should we confine these three axis to only record making? Or do we want to approach it in a holistic sense?

author: Slow Hand
content:
On reflection, the material benefits of *Option #1* are a nice selling point, but I think the bigger opportunity is to harness the superpower of rendering hit music at will. It would give me tremendous sway over the music industry once everyone comes to recognize that I can't miss. I would leverage that influence to make some positive changes where I can. Set up some institutions to cultivate and nurture the next generation of artists. 

Presumably, while the hit music I’m making runs counter to my personal tastes, it seems reasonable that it would still be valuable to *someone*. Just not to me. That will be my curse. I would dutifully churn out hits as fast as I am able to and gift humanity with a tsunami of unimpeachable pop awesomeness that will endure for a century. My sacrifice would be everyone else’s gain.

Counter-intuitively, by saturating the market with my personal brand of songwriting it would inspire the next generation of songwriters. Unable to compete with my torrent of sure-shot pop badness they would respond by writing new music that is the direct antithesis of my own brand of hits. With a little luck, the musical output of these writers would be exactly what I wished to hear all along.

That’s a win/win right there. I just have to suffer a bit. I choose *Option #1*.

author: cian riordan

We were gonna just spend the weekend in the studio together and make sure the vibe was right... turns out I got roped into one of his rounds of speaker moving fuckery. The speakers were his giant UREI 813c's on top of these custom subs... very heavy... and only sitting on cinder blocks. He was deep down a Fuzzmeasure rabbit hole and we were just moving, shooting, moving, shooting, moving back, shooting, etc, etc. When we'd finally make a change to the speaker position that seemed listenable, that was always the first song he would play to hear the speakers, followed by Back in Black. It's one of those few songs that's just cemented in my brain from hearing it so much -- like when you leave an image on a TV screen and it burns in -- that's that song in my ears.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Man… this is something I wrestle with a LOT in todays climate of “send the artist home with a track! Send to the label halfway through the session!”, and honestly I just don’t do it anymore. Demo-itis such a real thing that everyone is convinced they don’t suffer from, and sending out something wrong but fast has ALWAYS fucked me in the end. I just do my best to gas light everyone into thinking it’s ok to give it a day and that perspective is one of our most powerful tools in making great music. Otherwise everyone gets hyped, listens to a song 38 times that night (to a track that won’t come out for 7 months) and convinces themselves that’s how it should sound and now comping etc become an uphill battle. I really really really hate the “this immediate comp sucks but its quick” mentality.

(This is not to be confused with tracking things quick and dirty to catch a vibe, which I’m very much for. Write drunk, edit sober)

author: Brian Reynolds
content: So I climbed into my 2010 Volvo S80 today. And for the first time in 2025. I was going to listen to my music on the speakers. I plugged in my usb c adapter. Into the coaxial cable that runs into the center console, for that true old analog gold plated warmth. Turned the windows and volume all the way up, then as I prepared to hit play. I was blanketed with the all to familar tension. That very same feeling from when I was going to have to sit next to one of the two dudes on the middle school basketball team. Who took as their daily task, to pay homage to ancestral animal social structures, by drowning any nearby male counter part with sack taps, donkey punches, and nail whip flicks. You just preemptively flinch at the inevitable pain from their onslaught. I hit play on a mix that is -5.8 lufs at peak. No proverbial donkey punch to my thighs this time. The song didn't overload the speakers at any point. As I heard the mix in my studio. I heard it here. The things I loved about it. I loved it here. The things I was unsure about. I was equally unsure about them here. My eyes welled up a bit with fulfillment and gratitude. It took me longer and cost more than I could of ever imagined, when I started this journey. But I got here. No longer do I have to worry about translation of the mix. I can focus all my worry on the feeling and vibe of the performace. I'm willing to let my ego have this one, this mix punches with any modern mix on earth. On any system. (Sounds killer on the Meta Ray Bans. And those speakers are rutheless honest. Ive heard alot of overloaded low end mixes on em) And back to the gratitude. I wanted to thank this place. I couldn't have done it without yall. I'd still be in a pitch black room looking for a switch that felt like it was hidden on the ceiling. Now back to work! Have a great day yall!!

author: spectrummasters
content:
This completely resonates with me. The business of music doesn’t sit as well with me as the business of construction. There’s a camaraderie and kinship in physical labour on construction projects, and an embodied intelligence in that world that offsets the subjective and (for me) atomised work of hours alone mixing.

When I’m doing construction work, I’m also free to think objectively and from a distance about my audio engineering work.

Most of all, something changes for me when I’m being paid for musical “work” that I’m not entirely happy with. I’ve discussed this privately with a few folks here, and it seems the relationship between music and its commodification is problematic for more than a few of us. Simply put, it’s sometimes less enjoyable — though equally amazing — being paid for a passion.

I couldn’t recommend a construction or skilled trade career enough. It’s incredibly flexible and offers a tonic to music careers: you know you can walk onto a site tomorrow and get paid quickly and well. It’s always going to be around, and in my case, the certifications allow me to consider migrating to most economies globally as a skilled worker.

Construction allows me to be my own patron for my musical endeavours, and that feels really good.

I’d love to see a bigger debate here about how working in the upper echelons of the music industry feels long term — challenges, payoffs, economics, job security, retirement, healthcare, family life versus work life, and a world where socialising is networking.

Construction is a simpler engagement: competency, find a solution, do the work, go home.

I came across @cian riordan discussing becoming a fireman on Conversations, and much of what you said, Cian, is exactly what I get from construction.

I love how for you, though — instead of the firehouse bell calling, it was multiple Grammys!

author: Deleted User
content:
I don’t think there is a single person that was smartest or wisest. People all have different areas they are smart in, or wise in. The most intuitive, most empathetic, most knowledgeable (in ____), etc

I don’t really know what smart means, but people that appear smart are very nuanced about the things they don’t know or understand. They can articulate what they know, they can put things together with intuition, they can develop ideas and concepts without being fed one.

My observations of people with great wisdom seem to be the people who spend great deal of time processing emotions and self reflection. And they share what they learn from the place of empathy. 

I had a guitar teacher, he never gave me “real answers” to my questions. He always told me at the end of his version of guidance and helpful tools or some joke (again not an answer)“you’ll find the answers to any questions inside you”. Which was a wtf moment to me because I wanted the answer right then and there- but I realized often times a lot of things that are not factual cannot be answered by anyone but me because even if anyone gave their own version of answer it would not be relevant to me or I wouldn’t understand any of it unless I can make sense of things myself. That was one of the greatest and live changing advice I have received in life.

author: cy (sigh)
content:
only point I disagree with is music (art) not being essential.  and I think in a lot of ways ppl not seeing it as so is a key problem overall. 

no its not food but we're so used to having access to some form of it (good or bad, to our taste or not) that I think it gets undervalued overall. (obviously outliers exist)

I've literally seen art save lives. mental and emotional health is a necessity and music (even sound in general) I find is a key element. 

a ridiculous amount of cultures (read:indigenous) placed immense value on the art in their culture..often as part of their spiritual beliefs. even colonists co-opted and modified songs to allow conquests though culture more easily.

I think accessibility makes us think art isn't a necessity. it is. a lot of us would probably have lost our minds at this point (and I've seen that happen) if we didn't have it to lean on for various aspects. I'm not saying it should be #1 priority but I do think the inherent value we (the world) give art can directly affect how we value other things 

it's also the source of community and support for a lot of people and we are community based beings at our core  (though we can seperate to some extent).

the mindset things is also v interesting. being from Haiti I see American payment mindsets and European (a lot of both out there) and there's also more traditional ones that are more based in community - usually ones that survived colonialism to some extent. see:taino culture (mostly survived in pr, almost non existent in the other islands now). those are more focused on everyone getting there part fairly. the work is for the community not for yourself. while juxtaposition w the other mindset has flipped some folks' wayof working a lot of them are fine as is.

there's  o clear solution to the value of art thing. diff fields and different positions have to find ways of presenting value but I see that as a Consequence of the mentality we've adopted not a solution

author: Deleted User
content:
So I wanted to take some time to write this down and share it with you guys. I recently watched Jeff Ellis talk about his mixer brain concept and it really clicked for me this time. I think it ties in a lot with what’s being discussed on here and what I think even was the main theme to the conversations podcast. It’s about Regaining the Connection to your Senses. 

For a long time now I was living in a kinda “numb” state where everything I listened to, looked at, tasted, touched and smelled was “overruled” by my rationality (what I would describe as a sixth sense). So I was constantly living in this thing where my rationality dictated my connection to my surroundings, which lead me to be in a very anxious, depressed kind of state obviously reflecting back at my work. 

Now with that realisation I started practicing focusing on just on sense at a time, like putting my visual sense in the foreground or just deeply listening and so on. It immediately set back the rationality sense in a way, where it would leave the space to really experience the emotion of the stimulus. 

It really feels great and I want to take a moment to really thank everyone on here for leading the conversation to a better place. Big love for you guys ❤️

author: Slow Hand
content:
There's an old group of avant garde European intellectuals (Situationist International) who really dug into the idea of unstructured urban exploration - what they call a *dérive*. 

It can involve walking *through* buildings, up stairs, knocking on doors, following scents and aromas, following sound, talking to people, picking a psychological concept and using that as your guiding principle. The objective is disorientation and shaking yourself out of your usual ways of engaging with your environment.

It can be a *lot* of fun to do with friends who are down for an adventure. Just step out your front door and start asking questions and following your nose.

author: Slow Hand
content:
People who don't win Grammys will never be losers unless their goal was to compete and win a Grammy. Then they're losers by their own competitive standard, and losing is all part of the game.

Everyone else can only stand to gain by being nominated. The act of being nominated is a reward in it's own right. It's a net positive and validating moment for anybody's career. While it may be disappointing not to win, hopefully they'll never feel that they're losers for failing to win something that they didn't ask for.

This is all to say that it's a matter of mindset. If you're not actively trying to win a Grammy, then a loss shouldn't be construed as some demeaning thing and the nomination is still a net positive. I don't think it's on the Grammys to regulate people's emotional state.

author: chadwahlbrink
content:
I often use the proMB freeband mode as a basic “denoiser” for high end. 

If I get a vocal with some schmutzy noise, I will dip the high end, but have the lower vocal fundamentals trigger expansion back to a “flat” frequency whenever the vocal is actually singing. Release time to taste from there.

Can also help with an over resonant drum or lower “hum” issue where you want to dip most of the time, but then have it be “flat” whenever the snare hits, or whatever.

Comes in handy for post work too. Cleaned up a lot of VO’s and SFX recordings with those methods.

author: BatMeckley
content:
It’s just an entirely different product, and entirely different type of people on the spectrum that make it.

I don’t want to assume too much about any particular software business but I assume you’re building software to solve a problem. There’s a right and a wrong way to do it, and a price to come in at. (These rivets will hold up under this amount of stress up against this material so your plane doesn’t fall out of the sky). With music and production, the goal is a lot more amorphous, especially outside of pure radio pop production (I’ve already beaten that horse dead here.) The concepts of done and value are much harder to define because it’s in the eye of the beholder. 

Then, there’s the specific people. Most people that are in software or data management didn’t grow up going “I WANNA BE IN DATA MANAGEMENT”. They fell in to the field because they had an aptitude for it, were good at numbers, and it was a good way to make money so they can pursue their passion outside their job. With musicians, they specifically ran from that kind of life, the music IS the passion. A guy like cian or Noah could make a factor of 10 time more money in another field, but the emotional value they get from their work supersedes that.

It’s just chalk and cheese.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Sure! But probably not for the reasons many would think, it’s not just about having a lot of low end, but it’s character and how it sits and feels:

1. Bad For Me by Stacy Ryan (Castelli mix/Becker master) — so much lows to be for this type of vibe, and like .05 db more in 200ish area would be too much. LOVE how it sits on the edge there, but I’m a big Jon fan so no surprise

2. Disco Break 2 by Brasstracks (Castelli Mix/Becker master) — crazy good and deep transients with a wonderfully articulate but big low end. Quite dynamic, maybe slightly on the edge there so great to study translation to streaming. Recommended to me by the wonderful @YianniAP 

3. 30 for 30 - T Shyne. Not quite sure who mixed it, but I actually DON’T like the lows, or really the overall mix that much as an engineer but there is such a wonderful energy to me, this thing played before a sports game or a workout is it. So I have it here to remind myself that not everything has to be amazing sonically to feel great. Actually don’t like the low end on this at all, but the record still hits for me. Told @alexstein this was on the warm up list…he was like “why??” haha. Because I think my job is to love records for what they are and understand why they work, hopefully be more of themselves, not some target curve that’s ideal to me. and this is a great example of something like that

Also just have to mention that “Tattoos” by Georgia Webster is on there…probably my favorite vocal I’ve ever heard. @YianniAP mix Nathan master, I cannot look away from the vocal and the mid density is perfection to me

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
I’ve referenced this more than once in conversations here and in DMs with various people but it is remarkably applicable to what we do too if you can open up the aperture a little 

Musk’s Engineering Philosophy:

Musk overviewed his five step engineering process, which must be completed in order:

**1) Make the requirements less dumb.** The requirements are definitely dumb; it does not matter who gave them to you. He notes that it’s particularly dangerous if an intelligent person gives you the requirements, as you may not question the requirements enough. “Everyone’s wrong. No matter who you are, everyone is wrong some of the time.” He further notes that “all designs are wrong, it’s just a matter of how wrong.”

**2) Try very hard to delete the part or process.** If parts are not being added back into the design at least 10% of the time, not enough parts are being deleted. Musk noted that the bias tends to be very strongly toward “let’s add this part or process step in case we need it.” Additionally, each required part and process must come from a name, not a department, as a department cannot be asked why a requirement exists, but a person can.

**3) Simplify and optimize the design.** This is step three as the most common error of a smart engineer is to optimize something that should not exist.

**4) Accelerate cycle time.** Musk states “you’re moving too slowly, go faster! But don’t go faster until you’ve worked on the other three things first.”

**5) Automate.** An important part of this is to remove in-process testing after the problems have been diagnosed; if a product is reaching the end of a production line with a high acceptance rate, there is no need for in-process testing.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
As a former (what I would call pretty high level) athlete, I actually think about this thing very intently with regards to working on records and draw from things from the past life. Mine is more focused on how I want to hear (or rather deeply understand how I'm hearing) every day as close to consistent as possible, given we are human of course.

My 2 cents (which of course is just my experience): 

Some sort of routine before you work. Mine is that I wake up almost exactly at the same time every day, will work out at similar times (if possible), literally eat the same thing basically every day before during the work day, coffee at similar times, have  the same routine when I sit down to start work. Not all of that is possible or useful for everyone, but I think we can all find something that would focus us in a way that's useful and ablet to be put into practice for us.

Truly I find it helps a lot. We are physical beings, how our systems and bodies interact can definitely matter, especially in our ability to be available to the music.

That said, sometimes things happen and you gotta go. You will be tired, stressed, whatever. You have to do excellent work under those conditions too, it might be the most important skill if we are being honest about making a career of this. So training specifically for when you feel rough is definitely something I personally find important.  Which is where physically training helps, it's a way to force yourself into (fake) adversity and train response

@Slow Hand I know you know all this, just my experience

author: peterlabberton
content: Thinking about numbers, i.e. a 2 db boost vs 4 db, and then endlessly ABing/being conservative with moves to a fault. At my old staff engineer gig I got to assist Joe Chiccarelli on a handful of tracking/mixing sessions. The most eye opening was assisting him mixing the latest Hellogoodbye record. He’d mix 2 songs a day on average, and just breeze through cranking on the 550 eqs in the console—not a care in the world what the numbers said. I’d take recall notes and print stems/various mixes and he and the band would go have lunch/dinner. Seeing him repeatedly just crank on shit until it sounded compelling was huge. Obviously, you need to have developed the instincts to do that tastefully and have it sound great, but that sent me down a path of being fearless and trying to not get hung up on looking at shit.

author: Deleted User
content: recognizing if my reaction is coming from my taste or objective observation is another thing that guides me when I give feedback to others. I do mention my personal reactions but I try to be clear that it is my personal reaction not a real observation. But it’s very difficult, I’ve read from a book “nonviolent communication” once that the highest form of intelligence is making observations without making judgements. And I confuse these things often too. So I think it is a skill that can be applied to providing feedback. I also find it helpful to offer choices as feedback. For example, if (intention) is what you are going for trying (suggestion) may work well. But if (a different angle) is what you are going for, (a different suggestion) can be another thing you can try. This, I do more often as a producer. As casual feedback, I don’t do this very often other than people I am close to.

author: alecdibell2
content:
@absflores The bounces I send to clients are always labelled “in.prog” until we decide on the final mix.  It keeps things organized if they liked something about “in.prog1”, that we moved away from, and wanted to bring back in “in.prog3”.

I don’t send an in.prog until I feel just about done with the mix, or I want to ask the artist about their intention on a specific part of the track, before moving through that section of the mix. It’s mostly an organizational tool for me, and keeps the artist in the loop with the process being a collaboration

author: Rollmottle
content: What worked for me is liberating myself from the idea that every session and every song needed to be gold. You have to be OK with it just not happening some days, but you do have to make yourself put in the work. I have hundreds and hundreds of ideas that went nowhere, or sparked a new idea, or were the basis of some of my favorite work. And you are probably doing yourself a disservice by putting pressure on yourself to thread the needle every single time you go into the studio. That's exhausting. There are no harsher critics than ourselves. But sometimes noodling around aimlessly with no stated purpose or intention is what will get you there. Be OK with working for the sake of working and see what starts to happen.

author: frankieharper
content:
Thought for the end of the day… UK time 

Our arrangements and our mixes leap into existence from the womb of the metaphysical into a world rich in strict guidelines and predetermined boundaries. It’s drill, it NEEDS that thump… it’s lofi, it neeeeeds that blur, I want to get onto New Music Friday, it needs to be LoUd. 

Genre and playlists seem to rule with an iron fist… I often think that when an artist asks for a ‘brighter’ mix or an even MORE colossal 808. Not always… but often. 

Surely the overall and final sonic characteristic of our various musical expressions should be treated with as much emotional sensibility as our lyric or our narrative? 

Perhaps a dark lyric cries out for a dark mix… New Music Friday or otherwise?

Or is that built in?
 *wild generalisation hat firmly secured* 
Would it be too much of a reach to say that modern pop music is bright and loud because in recent history, pop music is high energy and bright in tone? Or is jazz historically observed from the back of a smoky leather bound room and so dark and dynamic just sits comfortably (whisky in hand) … I guess my question is… at risk of sounding a little Orwellian, do we control genre or does genre control us? Probably both? Asking for a friend.

author: Slow Hand
content:
American patriotism takes a lot of different forms. There is a certain amount of pride about the country that I find to well-earned and genuinely proud about. But depending on your social circles you're just as likely to find some people who take it way too far, and that's something that leaves a bad taste in my mouth. It gets pretty chauvinistic.

Patriotic rhetoric ends up being a lever used by politicians and adjacent political influencers to rally people to their causes (no surprise there), but lately it's mutated into a particularly ugly form and now there's a stark divide between people who have been radicalized towards extreme political positions and those who would reject them. One group unite under this brand of souped-up patriotism and the other tends to reject patriotic displays entirely because it resembles the first group.

No doubt you can find this behavior in lots of places around the world, but America's been feeling extremely polarized lately and overt national pride ends up being a symbol that's been co-opted by one group. So people here can be squeamish about it.

You'll likely be fine if you want to fly your American flag proudly. I don't want to dissuade you. Only highlight a little of our cultural baggage around that topic.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Imma take a different tack on this. 

My advice would would be - DON’T. 

First of all, as an engineer, “giving” ideas to the vocalist is not your job. I get wanting to be apart of the creative process, but your part is to capture, not to impose. 

Secondly, the minute you start focusing on vocal techniques, its gonna distract you from the things that actually matter. Things like vibe and being a good hang. 

Third: singing ideas *at* a vocalist is not nearly as effective as you might think. However good a singer you are, when you sing an idea they’re going to hear so much more than you intend, and will likely mimic things you’re not trying to convey. It can be more detrimental than you’d think. 

All that said- focus on learning each artist individually, create an environment of trust and respect, and when the time is right, you’ll know how  to offer insight. But not if you’re trying to from the get go.

author: Slow Hand
content:
There was a bit of talk in #👩🍳mixing-talk where folks were describing how speaking on podcasts refined their ability to speak.

To keep the audio/speaking analogies rolling, I constantly remind myself that word choice and vocabulary are akin to dynamic range in speech.

Referring to everything as "fire" at one end of the emotional range, and "shit" on the other end is akin to making a hyper-compressed track that's sausaged at 6 LUFS. It's exciting initially, but diminishes in effectiveness over time if there is no contrast from moment to moment.

If you can use finer and finer gradations of meaning to make your point, then your words have more heft and more expression with which to make them. 

Check it out:

Ehhhh. I found Collier confusing the fact that Rubin is wildly commercially successful with that being Rick’s intention. Like “if he’s wildly commercially successful it must be because he’s trying to be commercially successful, priority one”. Which I dont necessarily think is true. 

There’s often a chip on the shoulder of ultra high level musicians (and sometimes writers) that their talent doesn’t directly correlate to commercial success, and they’re salty at the people that they perceive less talented that do “better” than them (I call it the Jason Falkner syndrome). With writers it’s the guy salty that the only time people really want to hear their songs is when someone else sings them (the Butch Walker syndrome). I’m getting a little of that from Jacob here, which honestly really surprised me because he never struck me as that guy.

author: Joel "Roomie" Berghult
content:
Yeah for sure! Sounds like you're on a good path!! Totally understand the hesitation to delegate - especially that first 6 months-a year where you're acutely aware that helping someone else do it is *more work* than just rolling up your sleeves and doing it yourself. 

For building systems, what's worked for me is hiring and training your 'double(s)' first - someone with a similar skillset and sensibilities, very broad skills like me (who also did everything myself for a long time). This comes a lot easier if you have close friends in the same lane looking for jobs, I've seen people have their "double(s)" move in with them for a limited time too, with the intention of them soaking in exactly all you do.

Once my double(s) started doing pretty well, we started hiring more specialized people, and the doubles could then oversee their work, feedback etc - early on I would always be part of this, then slowly phase myself out.

What I wish I would have done earlier would have been to hire a producer/overseer/manager/'my boss' - someone with a bit more skin in the game/responsibility, and who keeps you in line if you start wavering. 

Again, I didn't love the setup of 10 and dissolved it eventually - as a creative it's easy to feel like you built a house/efficiency machine and one day you wake up and it's a prison that's not as flexible as you want. That's another thing I'm trying to keep in mind (I'm putting together a new similar team for this fall) - how do you keep the team agile and ready to shift when priorities shift? It could be as easy as accepting a little bit more churn & letting people go when they don't fit what's going on, but it's hard to let go of people you've trained and know well. I felt a friendship connection with my entire team, in hindsight I think that was a mistake too.

Those are some thoughts haha - what have you found so far? Are you experiences lining up with mine? What kind of roles are you hiring for?

The idea is to make sure when people do look you up, they're getting the right idea (updated credits, good visibility on your biggest work, and the kind of vibe you want to give off).

author: Zack Hames
content: If the alternative is to back home, I’ll try to offer some advice from personal experience. I moved to Richmond, VA for a year, got a job at a hotel doing audio visual. I quit my first commercial/post production gig doing ads full time. It was the worst but I was determined to keep working in music, and try to get integrated in the scene/studio world. It was a serious low for my mental health, the job was terrible, I was struggling and scraping by without any pay off. To make a long story short, I applied for a job back home at a big corporate company with a full time composition/post production gig, on a whim - I didn’t think it would get me anywhere. 3 months later I got the job and went back home after a year. I was out of the music scene back home at this point, and it took another year of reconnecting and working hard on my craft with friends who were willing to let me record their bands for the price  of drums heads and guitar strings, and honestly, those two things combined with some luck put me in a very secure and creative place, now making records for bands again that are paying decently well to boot. I don’t know how far you are in your career/journey, but I’m barely anything and have been recording for 15 years. It took me 5 years out of school to get barely a living wage and working lots of different types of audio jobs while making records, to get to a comfortable place emotionally, creatively, and financially. I’d bet almost anybody in this discord has a very similar story. It takes a long time and like others have said, there’s no one way to get there. Just keep doing you and trying to work on things that you enjoy.

author: Slow Hand
content:
This is definitely an interesting period in AI developments. Lots of exciting and novel tools exploding right now that are threatening to replace certain modes of illustration, writing, programming, and audio.

It seems likely that certain roles for creators are going to be diminished. Photography was a huge blow to illustrators when it emerged. Portraiture and photo-realism used to be the domain of painters. But when those skills became trivially easy to replicate the next generation of painters had to pivot into something else that played to the unique strengths of painting. I can't say what the actual causation is for sure, but the entire 20th century was dominated by abstract representation in painting, as one example of what that shift might look like.

Perhaps as creators our domains will need to shift into something else. Something more taste-driven and creative.

These AI tools can emulate pre-existing material well, but they still lack creativity, taste, and informed judgement. So I think the roles that are likely to remain (until another massive development) are matters of taste and curation. Somebody still needs to steer these tools to make something useful or novel.

author: LAPhill
content:
I know I'm an outlier here as a composer, but I very much feel the spirit of the question and would like to offer a few thoughts. My job is about realizing someone else's vision and pushing that to be the best it can be. If you're being hired as a producer, then like me, you have to believe that you're being hired for your taste and perspective. So the question is, why doesn't it feel good to you? Is there something undiscovered that could make it better?

I've written a lot of music that's outside of my aesthetic or personal tastes. But if I'm on the project, I'm going to be 100% invested in helping make that thing what it needs to be. There's a way into music that's outside of your vibe - sometimes it's getting excited about new techniques, sometimes it's exploring a genre you're unfamiliar with, and sometimes it's just because the people you're making music with are a good hang. Sometimes, the role of a composer (or producer) is to take their vision and find the version of it that **does **get you excited. We've probably all had that experience of "I really never listen to X, but this one song/artist is just undeniable." So strive for that.

author: Zach Hughes

My relationship with things I do not understand is usually conditional on whether those things have antagonized me, wowed me, or are necessary to contend with for my work. One or all are enough to fuel my curiosity and engage the pursuit!

I’m stealing this line from Arcane season 2: “there is no joy in perfection only the end of pursuit”. That stuck with me. From such a great moment in the show. 🤐

At present if I have chosen pursuit I then find the people, organizations, and institutions that have been honored most for their contributions to the thing I don’t understand. Not because they “know” and I don’t but because they are further along in the pursuit. I follow the breadcrumbs they have left, meet other fellow travelers, and maybe catch up enough to some to say hi. 👋 

I am a willing and / or disgruntled object pushed into motion by that which I don’t understand and I am also intentionally searching for what is precious to me.

Man I’ve given this thing a lot of thought in my lifetime. Honestly over the last few years I’ve realized my biggest limitation is my taste. I can learn anything, or hire a person who already knows how to, but I have to have the vision. The hardest part is to think to do it. 

So we’re all informed by our taste, and we’re all chasing the sounds we love, and we’re all trying to make a living by finding where our tastes overlap with a broader audience. 

It’s not that we’re driven by dark playlist overlords, is that the search of overlap in our tastes finds us all in that domain. Does that make sense?

author: Ross Fortune
content:
For the time of year that’s in it, I’m going to pose a question for the group, and dissect the question and its intent while doing so.

*What are your resolutions (and I don’t mean 24/32bit  👀) for 2023 and 2024?*

—

Are there better ways to frame the question to get more from asking it of oneself? 

I liked @Rollmottle’s comment “this is one of my efficiencies to gain for next year”. It made me go rewrite part of my list of goals for 2023 and 2024, and add some others.

How about “what are your greatest weaknesses (in every respect) that you’ve identified and made a concrete decision to work on this year?”

Do all of your resolutions/aspirations/goals align with each other? Have you chosen them holistically? (ie, how are you going to navigate “spend more time with family” alongside “work on twice as many records”?)

What about: “what have I done wrong up until now?”

author: jantrit
content:
@austenballard  On a similar thread I try to frame those situations like this. There’s no point worrying about something because if you can’t change it why worry and if you can, change it so you don’t have too. A huge simplification but something I find helpful with dealing with tough times in a studio. 

You can get that weird moment in a session when something goes wrong  usually the best course of action is to be a positive and hopeful force for the band or artist to rely on. 

“Let’s get this sorted as quickly as possible and get back to work”
Deep down I don’t think anyone really thinks you’re responsible for what ever happened, they’re just looking for a solution. Except of course Trevor, Trevor knows you did it and he’s mad. 

Lol but really sessions are emotionally intense situations and places and sometimes that can boil up in interesting ways.

author: Zach Hughes
content:
I've got a question for the crew that hopefully will lead to some interesting discussion but honestly could use some outside perspective here.

How important is it that we as collaborators come to a consensus on what feels good for the production of a song? Let's say you as a producer are not vibeing with the artist's direction / vision for a song, but the artist feels very passionate about their vision. You help them realize their vision all the way through and it still doesn't feel good to you or any other involved party other than the artist. What then?

I'm curious to hear some thoughts on the producer's perspective and the artist's perspective. To paint the extremes a little bit; at what point does being disagreeable as a producer (when dictated by your own taste / gut / intuition) become a hindrance to the project or unprofessional? And for the artist at what point are you getting in your own way so to speak and diminishing the potential outside contribution from collaborators that could level up your work?

author: matthewrederburg
content:
I think about the artistry of house music a lot when I work my small FOH gigs. It’s the question of “when the comparison between this canned music and the live performance is made, what do I want the results to be”

One solution that I love is choosing very benign music. Instrumental jazz, what you might call “wallpaper” music. Great music in it’s own right but chosen because:

1. it’s usually different in genre than the acts on stage. A local band in a small venue shouldn’t have to compete with the sound of the biggest records of the genre, even if everyone in attendance would dig the vibe.

2. Less attention grabbing than the acts on stage. Makes the live music seem big and provides a polite tapering down of energy at the end of the night. Sends the message of “the night isn’t over, but wasn’t the band you came to see the hightlight? Let’s simmer in those good feelings.”

Just a few thoughts about one approach. Not always the move.

author: Dereck Blackburn
content: The only thing I have to contribute is I work with folks in the 23 - 35 age range regularly (Im 44) and younger people who are HUNGRY to move up and ahead in their career get easily frustrated that things don't just happen for them when they're feeling like they're sacrificing a lot for very little recognition. There is also a lot of pushing and pulling the artists to fit their expectations instead of serving the art and letting nature take its course. Specifically theres a lot of "I can't wait to help you realize the full expression of your music and art when we work together!!!!!!!!" kind of vibe which is great internally but puts off older artists a little bit. I've seen it a lot over the last couple years with young producers and engineers and I wonder if its because of the pandemic, honestly. The whole "check list to success" thing is another good point. Some things are not easily repeatable or scalable with the expectation of the same result every time.

author: Zack Hames
content: As an engineer/mixer, How do you keep the perspective of the musicians you work with? After so many of years of being on the recording side of the glass and recording myself every day, I find myself forgetting what it would be like to trust someone else to record or mix something I’m creating. A lot of my thought process is on “finishing” and “by any means necessary”. I often wonder if I’d be as open minded as a musician in a band in a studio as I try to encourage my clients to be. For example, using someone else’s gear, the engineer making bold mix decisions/production choices, adding parts, etc. obviously some of these boundaries should be set before you dive in deep into a project. What are things that the musicians are thinking/experiencing emotionally I might be overlooking?

author: Zack Hames
content: I think the fact that you’re reflecting on it is meaningful. The reality is, for a lot of artists, we may be their first recording experience, their first record, etc and they’ll grow a LOT during and move on and grow. I think this was mentioned In the Conversations podcast. So for me sometimes it’s letting certain things go that aren’t going to change in someones performance and trying to make it work. I did a pretty emo influenced record recently, and the vocalist isn’t the best. I tried to give him tons of vocal tips and train him the best I could, and it ultimately made it so much harder to record him because it sounded so unnatural and unemotional. We ended up using a lot of earlier scratch takes for certain songs (and they feel super good/relatable/captivating even though it’s maybe nasally) and then using particularly emotional driven takes at the very end. I think there’s a balance of being honest/giving feedback and being delicate/not destructive in your response. Also, @oaklandmatt , your point about learning 10 different ways to say something needs to be better, is spot on.

author: Zack Hames
content: To elaborate @Eric Martin  , I think keeping a positive vibe and confident presence can let them relax about what they want at all and simply trust and not get super worried or hung up. Sometimes if start explaining “well X, Y and Z because then...” they start to get anxious or overwhelmed or even MORE focused / lack confidence on the thing.

author: Rob Domos
content: This mentality can help you squeeze more quality out of yourself as long as it’s truly objective. I’ve had multiple artists play me stuff that is objectively better than their references and their idols and they still won’t put it out because they see it as not perfect yet when perfect doesn’t really exist, or because they aren’t hyped on it anymore which is really just a symptom of them working on that song until they are sick of it and has nothing to do with the inherent quality of the song.   I think the message here is “look at the quality of this piece of art truly and honestly and release it when it hits the right marks”. That message works in both directions.

author: Zack Hames
content:
I love the short burst aspect of this a lot, I never would have thought of that. For lyrics, I have mostly done “journal entry” per day to amass tons of material to pick through later. I realized years later that almost all my completed songs with lyrics came from those bits of writing so I think I need to go back to that! (I don’t write lyrics a lot anymore).

For the music aspect, I relied heavily on just pure instinct / jam it out for so many years, but working on commercial music made me start to set a lot more intention in my writing which helped immensely in all aspects. I guess my favorite thing is mostly to try to write a fully structured song in a day (4-5 times a week). The limitation of a day gives me enough flexibility to actually create and record an entire track while also not getting TOO hung up on writing a verse, chorus, bridge, etc. there’s no time to overthink!

author: oaklandmatt
content:
@Zakhiggins the best producers in the world are great because of this. getting the best out of an artist/ vocalist. your job should be getting the best performance. most young artists change their vibe around a fancy mic in a studio. some of them show up and kill it. your job is to adapt and find that vibe quickly, while being super comfortable. this job is way more psychology and vibe than technical know how!

we recorded the hives vocals on Tik Boom with an SM7 on a straight mic stand in front of Pelle's live wedge monitors. HE knew that's how he could rock out the most and get the best vocal.

eric valentine gave Adam from Taking Back Sunday a neumann hand held condenser on a long cable so he could move around the room and perform.

i just figured out how to edit them after the fact. they weren't as clean as standing in front of a U47 with a pop screen. but they sounded fucking awesome

author: Zakhiggins
content: So how do you give someone feedback on improving their music if it's completely subjective?

author: Josh
content: That’s exactly what it is. There’s no universal system for what’s right and wrong. There’s just tailoring songs to certainly tastes.

author: Zack Hames
content:
The idea of “everything is subjective” is garbage because we live objectively. Very rarely are people simply unaffected or don’t respond to experiences. Not experiencing is still an experience.

The way you can give feedback to anything is to think about their goal or the goal of the piece. If they don’t HAVE one, then they don’t need feedback. I doubt anyone collaborating is often denying a response or feedback from another party. 

Not to mention, if a lot of people respond to something positivity or negatively, a consensus is built - usually around culture. Radio Pop music is popular because it’s approachable and simple (or appears to be) based on what our society has built into.

I’ll just stop here, this is an endless discussion. I find it frustrating to talk about because as “deep” as you can go, it feels SO surface level. but I think that’s a ME problem. Talking “Philosophy” never feels good to me personally.

author: cian riordan
content: When I first got hired by Eric as his assistant, I had already built a multi room studio complex and was making a living producing and engineering records. When I landed in LA for the first session, my mindset was “I can’t wait to show off all the knowledge and experience I had.” I very quickly ran up against the “nobody-gives-an-absolute-fuck-what-I-have-to-say-about-anything” wall. It was very clear that I was there to sit in the back of the room until I was asked to do something… order food, help with a mic setup, shuffle cars in the parking lot, etc. Not to mention working for someone like Eric who is extremely self sufficient… he was terrible at asking me to do things. It was always just quicker for him to do it… even if it meant getting up from the seat and walking all the way across the studio to adjust something. I made the absolute mistake in my second or third week of suggesting something to the drummer in the band after a performance. Eric overheard and pulled me aside. Basically said something along the lines of “yo, you really can’t do that. If you have an idea, run it through me. Absolutely inappropriate, however well intentioned it was. This was really deflating to me. I went from running the show at my own place to spending 14 hrs a day waiting for something to do.

author: LAPhill
content:
This has happened several times in the classical world, where unfinished works are completed either by apprentices of the composer, or someone that took it upon themselves to complete the work. More recently, when James Horner died during the scoring of The Magnificent Seven, his assistant/arranger finished the score. 

The difference between this and the pop example is there is no AI technology used to imitate the person, which feels like a parlor trick to me. I am all for finishing unfinished art, but unless there was an express wish from the artist to use their voice via AI tech, then I say make it known what it is. Finish the production by bringing in other people to celebrate the spirit of the original voice. Pay tribute. Sort of like Japanese Kintsugi, where you're drawing attention to what it's not to elevate what it is. (This is not the intention of kintsugi exactly, but I can't think of a better metaphor at the moment).

author: Barbara
content:
Even though I understand where you come from with this - I guess everyone relates and/or feels more emotionally connected with some projects than others - I think we should own what we do. If you're recording/mixing/producing, do it as best as you can. That can mean passing it on to someone else (and handle this part with care, in my opinion, is also a part of the job). But if you end up going all the way, it still is a worthy project, you should still give it 100% of yourself. Learn something new and useful. And if you do, you should be proud of having your name on something you know you gave your best (even if the rest of it wasn't ideal, your part was the best you could do, at least in a certain moment in time).

So, I'm all for: work in it, own it. But make sure you do your best all the times and always learn something.

author: Deleted User
content:
This can be controversial, but to execute C no matter what artist says or wants to do and present it. That way they can at least have a tangible result to compare it with. Instead of explaining, it’s better to do it and show it.

My humble take: our job is not necessarily doing what we’re told. it is to take their vision, and take it to a place where they could say “wow- I didn’t know this is what I wanted but this is what I want now”. Which I think is the taste and perspective factor. 

It is case by case of course and some artists could come in with A to Z manual of what they want, which can be cool- or not. I personally find those boring, unless I really admire their vision and it just feel like an honor to be a part of it. I think being a yes man can be a quick way to become dispensable. But someone who is willing to serve by giving you some friction that can turn into some heat 🔥 can be someone they find trustworthy and interesting. It’s case by case dependent, some people need perfect aerodynamics to accelerate their vision, and I don’t think that’s necessarily being a yes man- but rather about just being the right fit for the project and being someone who is fully on board to do what they are asking. 

But I think more importantly- it’s okay to miss. If they don’t like it - then scrap it or give it another go. And it’s also fine if you end up not being the one for the project

author: BatMeckley
content:
By all accounts she’s one of the best vocal producers/engineers around, so I’ve never had the chance to work with her. Can’t speak for her techniques. 

Revoice something I almost never use. In standalone melodyne on a lot of pop tracks if it’s a centered double I’ll make it spot dead on, almost to the point where it’s phasing, to beef up a lead to cut through a mix. If it’s singer songwriter Elliot smith vibe I’ll hard tune the double and for a tonal center and then let the lead breathe more to keep the character. Left Right doubles  you can’t tune as hard because they’ll start to collapse to mono which defeats the whole purpose.  

So again, it’s usually about working backwards from what you want, what it’s supposed to be, than it is about any one technique

author: Deleted User
content:
Fair enough. Everything that concerns “me” starts with working on myself. 

But my belief as someone who makes art; it is my job to be concerned about it, and spend time pondering on it. I’m not responsible or I can’t be for it, it would be an arrogance and narcissism (or ego centric frame of mind at the very least) to believe that I’m responsible for it or matters in any way - but I think believing that what I do would have no impact on others is inconsiderate. 

I believe it would help people find things they like if everyone alivned their taste/values to their individuality; rather than the idea of their individuality.

Re: Korea; 
you bring up a very good point about this. Korea is an extreme case of collectivism over individualism, and my obsession about this probably stems from growing up in that background. I only truly understand two cultures from first hand experience and that is Korean and North American; but it seems that no matter how culture forms, human nature will always be relevant and it’s in our nature to be want to be accepted, feel included. 

I believe that American individualist propaganda is a lie. It’s not about being yourself, it’s rather about finding a box to put yourself in for sake of convenience. i believe it mostly has to do with consumerism and the complexity of the society from immigration and various cultures coming together; converging / diverging at different pace even amongst those that share the same cultural roots- which then later becomes nu-gen X-American culture, which is different from the culture of X. (X being a country/ethnic group)

author: Chase H
content:
nice!!! The big takeaways I get  from Kant are him pointing out certain preconditions for the possibility of experience/knowledge at all.
 If those preconditions aren’t the case then experience itself is impossible.
In short, if one’s worldview denies the possibility of the things needed for experience or knowledge to be possible, then that person can’t even make knowledge claims at all without being self refuting

He was trying to respond to Hume after David Hume tried to nuke Metaphysics. 

Kant like other German idealists is a reallt dense read, a philosophy teacher on YouTube named Daniel Bonevac has some great videos on Kant that distill it down into way more palatable things to chew on if you felt like it.

author: Matthew The Cooke🎄🎅🏻
content:
**-) **Offline experiences might be a song or an artist being tied to a memory I cherish - that song played at that party when I kissed a beautiful girl, that song played when I was walking out of the bar piss drunk at 6 am with my best friends, that song I heard when I was at a music festival 10 years ago and the world was a better place etc, that song makes me laugh my ass off everytime I hear it (shoutout Frank Zappa lol)

**-) **It could also simply be a piece that moved me when I first heard it and it made me feel something - take for instance** LCD Soundsystem's** *"All My Friends"*, which is to me still the most poignant anthem about getting older, and it never fails to illicit and emotional reaction in me, even though I've never seen them live or have a specific memory attached to them. 

**-) **What makes me become a fan of an artist is - at least these days -  mostly determined by how consistently the artist's work can get an emotional reaction out of me. Take **Bleachers** for example - I had been aware of them for years, but only with this year's album and after discovering "Hey, their songs are actually ALL that good" I became a fan. 

**-)** There are a only a handful of bands/artists I consider myself a hardcore fan of., where I truly explored their entire catalogue over and over again, and it was almost always because they just continued to impress or move me

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
I don’t think this is a hot take. Wind & String instruments and the human voice are all kinda impossible to make into a virtual instrument in a completely human sounding way. 

But, a world-class ensemble is often a little out of reach for a lot of self-producing artists and young folks just getting into it, and while something to strive for, shit talking BBC orchestra in this context feels shitty. 

The key is to do interesting things with what you have. Can’t hire the LSO? Make something intentional that gives the same feeling if not the same Sonics.

author: BatMeckley

On to the next dove. Or this time an eagle. Or a dolphin. Or some other protected species. It’s fun to venture into new territories and try to get good. 

I’m pretty anti participation trophies. They feel like coping mechanisms. I’d rather hold myself accountable and set ambitious yet realistic goals, and then try to achieve them, whether it be “produce a #1” or do 300 pushups in a week. I like to have an objective measuring stick.

Skrillex currently has the hardest sonics (loudness plus emotion). For me, acoustic rock drums peaked in their excitement for me in the late 90s/ early 2000s era.
