author: MosesSOG
content:
I rather enjoy this question. Strategies to stay optimistic in 2026. 1-is a compelling vision! A a vision of the future that is exciting and has enough "impetus" or "unction" behind it to get me excited about the work i am taking on and gives me a thorough enough reason to wake up every day. 
2. - consistent prayer and a meditation practise. taking time to do things to ground my self spiritually. i also consider in thiss area study, and fasting at times, and even deliberate training and nourishment - essentially those things which benefit a spiritual life and overall well being
3. living in awe, or allowing yourself to be amazed. intentionally finding things that speak to me or captivate my mind. it is a continuous journey sometimes what used to inspire no longer does so regualy finding things that light my mind up.
4. collaboration/ contribution to a collective whole. there is nothing better than creating something awesome with afriend or brother. that is something that i do take great delight in. creating in a solitude - there is a time and place. yet if i am not connecting with people i love then it feels empty.
5. rejoice. be merry. taking time to celebrate. realizing all of this can be gone. so doing my best to keep that in my mind. there are people in much worse situations, no matter how hard it gets. and there are people who currently wish they had what i had.

author: Slow Hand
content:
What you describe feels like what I think of as "conceptual alignment". When the essence of the song is fully realized because all elements are working in harmony (or sometimes appropriately discordant).

On those records the underlying emotion and message are expressed when the chords, melody, lyrics, sonics, and performance are all working in service of that thing. Every element is pushing in the same direction. They feel aligned.

Like a classical painting in which you can *feel* a strong emotion immediately because the composition, expression of the figures, color choice, and flow of movement in the image are all "pointing" at the underlying essence.

Does that sound at all like what you're experiencing?

author: Josh
content:
I mean, yes and no. 

It’s not about if it’s just good or bad. 

It’s about if it matches with the audience. 

There are great songs that can’t make it on the radio. There are great songs that can’t be played live because they don’t translate with the audiences energy. They still aren’t bad songs. Their intent is just different. 

I think you’re mistaking the idea of “bad” for “wrong”. 

There aren’t bad songs. There’s just wrong songs. Not every choice made during writing/production/mixing is going to resonate with everyone.

author: skinnybreakfast
content:
Sorry for the book incoming. But this is plaguing my mind. Has there been an in-depth discussion on live or in discord yet about musicians on tiktok? 

It's a crazy scene of selling your creative soul for 1 minute of attempting to go viral. and then if you do get a popular video, whatever that one was - that is now your thing... singing into a trash can doing RHCP covers... ok, now do another 100 of those.  I see so much talent on there, genuine talent and artists who have worked hard on their craft getting 10 views due to the algo... once the algo has tried your vid on a few people and it didn't stick the vid is dead... so it's totally hit and miss based on your first small sample of viewers.

I see this having a huge impact in many ways. On the plus - you are getting exposure to incredible new ideas, skills, trends, methods for being creative... on the negative it's demotivating to the nth degree, and cheapening the creative process, in my opinion.

Matt and Jon recently talked about track lengths getting shorter and shorter, now 2 minutes is the normal. Partly due to the attention span of people... well what is this going to do... 1 minute pop tracks incoming? Just gimme the hook in 30 seconds and let's move on please. :p. How can we get young people to lay on the floor and listen to 10 minute vinyl tracks again? In my opinion humanity NEEDS this :)) 

I also swear I've heard the influence of trending memes from tiktok coming through in music in the charts, but cannot really back this up.

What's everyone else's thoughts? I have a friend in LA who says everyone has gone crazy there for tiktok fame? 😛

author: skinnybreakfast
content: You said you're fine with 1 minute tracks right, which is fine and I get it. I have made a few myself that I like and found I expressed the feeling and emotion in that time and it didn't need more... but.... what if you are confined to 1 minute for every track all the time... your form of expression is going to change no? Can everything be truly expressed in 1 minute snaps. What about songs that keep you in the vibe and space by having space and time to unfold.... my concern is everything is getting shorter and shorter with tiktok being a big influence. instant gratification, move on, "i need to find the next hit for my brain", swipe swipe. this speed, this haste... how is there any chance for music to settle, sit and unfold in the listeners mind? --- and even if you manage that, it's gone almost instantly as they continue swiping for the next "hit".

author: Slow Hand
content:
I think a good example of someone who represents that shift is the painter Mark Tansey. 

His paintings, while photo-realistic, don't derive their value from their resemblance to the real world. Instead their interest lies in their allegorical representation of people and places. Their unique value lies in the curation of ideas and the story, concept, or idea that they convey. They're telling a pretty sophisticated story under the surface.

Look at these paintings. There's no individual element of either of these that I couldn't render right now with Dall-E and photoshop my own remake together. But right now AI is nowhere close to creating such a cohesive visual composition with it's unspoken message. For now great art still requires a human operator with intention.

It's crazy to revisit all of the things that you've forgotten. author: ALXCPH
content:
Let the man sing if he wants to! 🤠 I’d argue that having some musical experience/intuition is 10/10 times not a bad thing. No matter what your job is in the music making process. 

Sure it’s not the engineers job to give advice. But if an artist asks when they are stuck with something being able to communicate at the same language is never a vibe breaker. I’d even argue it could enhance “vibes” or confidence, as long as what is being said makes contextual sense. 

It might be different where you are or at your level. But where I am (lower level 😂) who ever is in the room is involved. And if the process is being respected. I’ve been in so many sessions where I’ve recorded an artist and they ask for a harmony advice, or even if we are vocal producing, being able to quickly sing a line to quickly reference a point in the song is so much. Faster then having to look for it.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I can't stop thinking about this idea of "Why don't you play something that people actually like?"

I personally wrestle a lot with the idea of making music *for* other people. It's simply not very high on my list of priorities. I'd say I'm self-centered in how I approach making music. I'm out to make stuff that *I* want to hear. Things that aren't being represented elsewhere. Flavors I've never heard. I'm not aiming for a broad appeal, but I'm also not shying away from it. I'm just not much of a people pleaser in that regard. I'm in it for the discovery and the exploration and the pleasure of making something that excites me.

I think often about that Steve Jobs sentiment of "People don't know what they want until they see it." I think about that a lot. I trust that if I follow what feels good to *me* then I'll get something valuable out of it, and maybe it'll connect with others. If not, that's alright too. I'll know that I've made something that feels great.

I sometimes worry about this because I've always felt that it puts me at odds with a lot of people out here trying to make excellent records. Sometimes our goals will align, but I just don't feel motivated by the need to appeal to a lot of people and that can also make us diverge.

I guess what I'm trying to say is that there's a different kind of taste that I'm trying to cultivate. It's one that runs parallel to the kind of taste that is good at appealing to a large number of people. I feel as if I'm aiming at an entirely different goalpost from people playing the other game. I want to tickle people in a way that they didn't know they were capable of. That's what's thrilling to me.

author: Will Melones
content:
I get the impression that *your* taste is both incredibly diverse and highly refined, and while it may not align with the general public, it’s far from “bad taste”. I also don’t feel like someone who only likes to listen to the top of the charts has better taste, although you could say it’s empirically true that they do.

The fact that you’ve deliberately chosen to create something that’s not for everyone brings me back to the Conversations episode about the Service-Artisan Continuum. There’s no need to plant your flag on the service end of the spectrum if it doesn’t bring you joy and there’s food on your table. And there’s nothing that says you can’t serve clients by day and let creativity run wild by night.

If you’ve got something profound to say, it would be a damn shame to water it down for the public’s taste. I don’t think Radiohead would have had the impact that they did if they’d written another “Creep”.

author: shaunobi
content: I resonate with what Jos says above. I've experienced two things over time, both of which I called "burnout". The first is just emotional / creative exhaustion. I pushed it too hard and didn't take care of myself. Things that used to bring me joy hadn't changed, I changed, and I didn't want to look at them at the time anymore. Working out, taking time off, spending time with people you like / love that recharge you, hiking, this sort of thing can fix it.

author: spectrummasters
content: Good evening / good day to you ruairi . Just a quick one , I wanted to essentially thank you for sharing your appreciation of rx here as much as you have , making mention of your use of the spectral repair tool. I’ve been paying attention and taking notice and reflecting on what it is I’m trying to achieve with de Essers and Eq’s on mix elements  etc and this morning I just wasn’t getting the vibe I wanted from a vocal . It just wasn’t natural anymore . It felt perfectly bland . Your rx comments came to mind and I removed pretty much all the corrective inserts , opened up rx and between the magic tool (I found this good for the high end ) and the paintbrush (on the low end /plosives ) I pretty much sculpted the natural sound of the vocal all in rx , without any distractions. Just.....the sound ....of the vocal. Having finished and returning to the mix , it was everything I’d wanted with about a third of the plug in inserts. I’m a major convert to this upstream, approach . In this case it was a vocal but I’m intrigued to apply the principle on a master. The inspiration came from yourself. Thanks man .

author: peterlabberton
content:
Alright frens, seeking… wisdom? Advice? A gig? (Lol.)

I’ve wanted to live in nyc my entire adult life and never have—it’s never made sense to do it career-wise and probably never really will. But every time I’m there I feel totally at home and happy and excited in a way I don’t anywhere else. I spent a summer there several years ago and always linger as long as I can whenever I can, have close friends there (not in music), end up there usually a couple times a year and relish it every time. I feel like I know it as well as is possible for never having been a resident.

I know the music biz there is pretty much defunct (at least compared to LA), and I really *really* don’t want to repeat the emotional and financial ruin that I experienced moving to LA and restarting everything 6 yrs ago… but from a non-career perspective it’s where I want to be.

All that said, I’m in it to fucking win it in LA for my career—though with an eye for sure on getting to a point where I can relatively comfortably make that move.

Any wisdom/experience on making a mid-career move like this from folks here? I’m 35 yrs old, some decent credits but not major traction yet, in a basically married but not actually married relationship with a school principal who is into the idea of a move there as well (though our finances are totally separate and I for sure need to earn!), no kids or desire/plan to have kids.

Any benchmarks/goals that might be reasonable to aim for before seriously starting to make moves on this? I’d do it tomorrow if I could, but would also stay in LA for 5+ more years no prob to set things up properly. Even open to things like a podcast (/radio?/other audio prod) gig to help smooth the transition if that’s reasonable to find and lucrative enough—but what I’m really looking for is how to think of this as a full time freelance record maker. Or if someone on here secretly is hiring for staff gigs at Electric Lady, plz lmk 😉

author: Will Melones
content:
Shouldn’t they care to know? I’ve heard so many people in my family say they have no musical talent or they’re terrible at piano, but they’ve never practiced for 15 minutes. What’s the measurable difference between Yo-Yo Ma and your uncle?

My gut feeling is that most of talent comes down to commitment/focus (interest in the craft) and learning styles, and then culture and early exposure mold that into an affinity.

Some people will suck at an art form, put in the work, and then not suck anymore. Some will be born with a brain that’s wired to seeing shapes, and find it easy to visualize patterns on a guitar neck. Some will be auditory learners and may find it easier to learn to identify intervals by ear.

And then some people will grow up singing or playing in church, and those people get the cheat codes from a *very* young age while their brains are still spongey, learning things like their first language. Of course they weren’t born playing the organ, but it can look that way from the outside.

It seems both mystical and defeatist when people who don’t think they have talent talk about people who do—almost like an excuse. And maybe that’s intentional, and exactly the point you’re making.

author: Rob Domos
content:
The idea that noise shaping can affect how we perceive frequency balance was my first thought for what your concern would be and I can get behind that. 

I’m curious about the statement that “it doesn’t survive further dsp processing”.

My thoughts are: while we typically don’t hear dither as a distinct thing that we can pick out and point to, we do hear the effects of it in the combined signal, and I subjectively feel like each sound in a record has slightly more defined separating edges without dither, and I sometimes subjectively like noise shaping for giving me more of that distinction between elements in the mids. 

(Not that it’s very applicable for me anymore because I stopped dithering 24bit exports about a year ago after some rounds of listening and chatting with a bunch of my friends in the EDM world about it and i’m usually delivering at 24)

author: Deleted User
content:
there are traditional jazz and modern jazz. people who do traditional like to honor the head (the melody of jazz standard). A close friend of mine is a modern Jazz Saxophonist, he said he once broke up with his band after an argument because he didn’t want to play the melody but his band members were more traditional and wanted him to play the head. 

Imo calling something not Jazz because they aren’t doing the head-solo-head form is like calling modern classical music not classical music because of the aleatoric composition. Somewhat of a valid opinion, but not really. 

Would you call wayne shorter not a jazz musician because he writes scores for his band? (well… he’s also a free jazz musician…) 

For general public, traditional jazz and traditional classical music would be more appealing to listen to for most people due to the predictability factor. Modern classical music and modern jazz is a movement to explore creative possibilities beyond that, but… it’s often not done so tastefully because they step too far off the predictability.

But Jazz is a free form of expression. I think a lot of non-jazz musicians hate on Jazz because it’s somewhat cerebral (it really isn’t once you get past it… which I couldn’t just yet), and a lot of people choose music because of its unexplainable magic people experience from it. It’s only natural that the same people that was attracted to the unexplainable nature of music being turned off by the explainable nature of harmonies and rhythms. Jazz noobs and Berklee kids may make it look like that what Jazz is about and some have elitism behind it too, but that’s not jazz. All the theory and stuff is a door you go through to be able to step into the world of self expression with an open form. (to be fair many old school jazz musicians solely played by ear with no knowledge in music theory. because… it all comes from their ears at the end of the day)

Whether one wants to sit through someone expressing themselves is theirs to decide.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
**Sound, Feel and Peak Wow**

I suspect many Engineers have a similar trajectory when it comes to audio

- First your musical lights come on, often via your parents taste, an older brother or maybe school friends
- Sometime soon after you realize that music makes you feel like nothing else, it speaks to your interiority in a way that other arts do not
- OK … now you’re hooked and you start to wonder *why* sounds make you feel the way they do? You start paying close attention to the textures, the colors and the detail of audio
- Next you start working with audio and start learning how to manipulate sound. Soon you are chasing the work of your idols! Killer drums tones, deep verbs, tripped out delay throws, beautiful vocal textures … all the stuff we love
- Your journey continues and hopefully over time you have access to better songs, players, gear, rooms etc and the quality of your sonic output continues to improve

You may eventually arrive at “Peak Wow”

This is the moment where your ability and gear allows you to actually create and wield the sounds that set you on this crazy journey. Your mixes are wide, and deep and loud and impressive and hit and knock and do all of the things …. “WOW, that sounds amazing” ….

But notice we haven’t mentioned feel in a minute. Here’s what I think happens to a lot of Engineers, some graduate out of it and some don’t

Liken our journey described above to using your hands to make shadow animals on a wall. You probably don’t remember the first time you saw that as a kid but it’s wild! Pretty soon you’ve got a pair of bunny ears going, and maybe a swan or a spider

author: Zach Hughes
content:
Late to the party. I do like this question. 

For me #1 would probably be a 5. Something special about dancing with an idea that's been around for centuries or millennia even, but also very exciting to explore the cutting edge. Hard for me to pick one over the other.

#2 I'd go with a 7 maybe. If I knew more than anyone else about one thing I'm not sure that would maximize my wellbing / happiness. One of my great joys in life is to pursue the myriad of curiosities that bubble up in me. I would hate to neglect them. Besides there's a lot of cool shit out there.

#3 My default here is a 10. As much as that has been a gift and helped me navigate my career I'm not sure it's best for my wellbeing. My gf is probably closer to a 0 here and she is generally happier than I am and very successful in her career. Perhaps there's a more emotionally regulated way to view the long-term but I see risk, upside, downside.. If I'm not careful it can induce a lot of stress. I think I'd rather crank the slider closer to zero the older I get.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Thinking about REFs today on foot of a revision. Awesome artist, A list mixer. Has huge sine bass notes in a few sections that were chattering a bit with the short iZotope maximizer release. This mixer uses the same limiter setting on every mix and I copy it and work from non limited mix, sometimes tweaking slightly

So bass distortion sounds cool to me, but more importantly it was in the REF. So to my mind it’s cool and in the artist’s signpost of intention …. But they wanted it clean (which was possible and pretty easy)

I guess the message and the reason for putting it in general is that we’re all under the gun with deadlines, and all through the process there can be a sense of it’s just a demo, just a producer ref,. just a mix ref …. we’ll nail it later. But each girl or guy downstream is picking up on intentions from the REFs

author: Rukie
content:
the word “emotion” needs a better definition sometimes in the space we are in. 

Emotion isn’t necessarily something that you are always aware of “feeling”. Some reactions are merely state of mind, until it is given a name. Some reactions are visceral because of what the chemicals do to our body. 
sometimes, it’s neither visceral nor label-able. Which makes us assume that it’s not a feeling or emotion. But can we really differentiate emotions and thoughts? What exactly would differentiate them? 

On the other hand, there is music that pushes more, versus music that pulls more. 

Just like how audio is bipolar, we can’t have connections just be a one way communication. Tame Impala is a type of music that pulls. You don’t know why, but you just want to know “what was that song? I GOTS TO FIND OUT”. 

Push is more like… “I can’t unhear it” a lot of Pop hits are push with some pull factor. 

the ones that make you bummed out that you couldn’t shazam are ones that pull you in. it’s a slight push that gets you listening, and the rest of it is just pulling you in. (my own reaction when I first heard tame impala and couldn’t find out whose song it was)

Culturally, I think the love for (dreamy sound) can be explained with a desire to escape reality. 

So really, the emotional reaction is that “it transports me into a different space”. My theory on “why do people like that feeling?” is that many people aren’t happy with the reality of our lives because of economy and what not. And the idea of “escape from reality” became more and more a viable thing for us to want after experiencing digital devices and internet.

author: Will Pragnell
content:
Reflecting a little more, here are some important learnings I've had over the past decade or so related to things I don't understand:
- Don't avoid things just because you don't understand them (this seems really obvious but took a while for me to truly embody)
- If you want or need to understand something, you can - it's just a question of time, effort, and intentionality
- You don't always need to understand something to use it / work with it / benefit from it, and sometimes there can even an upside to not understanding (though the upside is almost impossible to predict if you don't understand - a paradox!)

author: itaylerner
content:
2 cents: I think it’s a “stars have to align” kind of thing (That’s why there’s a million artists but only 1 Beyoncé and 1 Post Malone) That combo of unique pov + excellent artistic taste + ability to express it all… it’s rare, to say the least.

I personally think, generally speaking, that a producers job is less about helping an artist craft their pov and more about supporting them in their process of uncovering and expressing it, Unless you’re extreeemely close with that artist. it’s really their job, as a human first, to process their experiences and develop their unique perspective. To become the most whole version of themselves, imho. 

Your job as a producer is to create a safe and encouraging space where they can explore and express it, say scary things, move forward in their ideas. It’s also your job to then facilitate the process at every stage, musically and otherwise, to make sure the execution is as good as it can possibly be. But the artist is the artist, it all comes from them at the end of the day.

author: Deleted User
content:
Thank you all for chiming in on this, it really got me thinking! I took some time to dig deeper into my uncomfort with this topic and I think it’s really just about the concept of a “personality trait”. Maybe we can jam a little on it.

I had this example in mind:
Let’s say we meet someone for the first time and while we’re interacting I gather that this person seems like a “happy person”, they’re smiling, giving off warm vibes and are kind. We keep on meeting this person and the experience repeats itself. So the more we meet, the more our idea that this person must be a “happy person” solidifies. We know of course that this is an abstraction and that the person is probably going to be sad, angry, etc. at times. 

Now let’s say we think, man I really liked this person they are so easy to deal with, I enjoyed every bit of our interaction. I wish more people would be like that! And there you go. Now you are set to figure out all the details about happiness, the factors that make a “happy person” a “happy person”. The warmness, the kindness etc. and help people be more happy. 

Now you’re really digging into it, you start making videos, writing blogs going out to teach happiness. People are really digging it and you feel like you’re doing good for the world. So the concept is in everyone’s mind happiness is what we should strive for and whoever is not happy enough yet just needs to try harder. Suddenly you’re watching the news and you hear more and more people are getting symptoms of depression, stress and anxiety. And you think to yourself wow how did that happen? I thought I was making   the world a better place. 

And I think that’s what’s happening with a lot of these concepts that once they get institutionalized or gain popularity they somewhat lose their initial intent and can even have a rebounding effect. I mean we can see it going that way with a lot of different trends like mindfulness, health awareness, the work life balance etc.

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content:
Snares or other sounds, I do have loose process that helps me move keep momentum and focus.

TLDR; It’s a contextual balancing act that takes both the context of the music and the studio environment into account.

Music Context

Phase 1 | Production
- 🔑 Everything will be refined later, so I focus on Momentum > Perfection.
- I feel the core energy of inspiration behind the track and go through sounds with the intention of finding one that captures the essence of the finished vision. Doesn’t matter if it’s excellent at this stage.

Phase 2 | Post-Production Mix
- 🔑 I revisit sounds with the intention to sculpt an emotionally enhancing space for the music to live in (small venue, living room, arena, efc).
- Refine sounds while keeping initial energy in mind, but you can focus more creativity on ‘mixing’ than ‘production’ (at least how my mind perceives them)
- Will likely need to replace a part of the snare stack, but now that more of the tracks vision has bridged the gap between vision to reality it’ll be easier to find a proper pocket and vibe for things. 
- Because that initial sound resonated with me, I’ll try plug-in sculpting before replacing, but I tend to add / replace the sound that emulates the rattle under the snare at this stage + add dimension for the emotional space I’m building.
- 🗒️ Sometimes a diff sample can come with these things off the bat no tweaking needed, its rare though.

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content:
I’m late to this, but wanted to say my part that I navigate DAWs based on the mindset of the workflow I’m intending to get into.

If I needa hit a new track quick to get a vibe set, FL Studio is amazing for quick production and quickly transforming the studio into a different vibe, but if I need to do a bunch of vocal takes and/or deep mixing juggling chains and transforming that vibe into a captured piece, especially those meant to become a product, I find Pro Tools Ultimate the absolute 🐝s 🦵s for that.

-

They may have patched it and this is old news, but I know FL can’t handle as much CPU and it used to run off of one processor, so my quad processor CPU can’t handle more than 20 tracks in FL, whereas I can I have 200+ tracks on Pro Tools and still run smooth (utilizing freeze and stuff too, which FL doesn’t have) so yeah.

In the end, once a threshold of quality for a tool is passed, it’s a matter taste based preference, and I find my taste varying with projects and my two DAWs capture all the different intentions I find myself having between the two different UIs / Workflows

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content:
Anything too deep into ‘audiophile’ territory feels most useful as fun fact research, rather than part of making music, for me.

When I was a kid I LIVED my music to get through hard times, listening to great artists on shitty headphones and cassettes - In that vein, I believe the energy of the creation trumps whatever sonic difference DAWs have, meaning whatever allows the creator to tap into that inspiration is what’s most important in the end, and my DAWs are best for me simply cus they remove points of friction in how my brain goes through its creative process.

author: Zach Hughes
content: Ok I’m new to it but there’s a framework called PANAS (positive and negative affect schedule) embedded in the science of wellbeing that put simply measures how often people visit positive vs negative emotional neighborhoods. Positive and negative affect are mostly independent. Some people experience a lot of both, some very little of either, and some are high in one but not the other.

author: Zach Hughes
content:
Originally I had thought optimism was an emotional layer or a disposition but after some reading trying to explain that PANAS framework it seems it might be more a layer of cognition. So the OG framing of optimism as something you practice seems more aligned.

That PANAS framework though is an interesting translation tool for interpersonal ‘thinking’ divergence from similar emotional stimuli. I dont know if that makes sense. But me and the gf were playing with ChatGPT going back and forth seeing how our varying affects might change our thinking from similar inputs.
